description:
HISTORY:See CONN-27 for the feature request related to this ticket. Also see CONN-56 a bug ticket opened by IV&V during 4.0 testing. 

BUSINESS VALUE: Compliance with the underlying IHE specifications. Participants can participate in the eHealth Exchange and onboard successfully. Help achieve CCHIT certification of product.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL: This ticket is to make sure that the PD messages both inbound and outbound are audited per the ATNA specifications as defined by the attached checklist - CL PD Responder Audit.xls.(Trying to get the initiator checklist as well from CCHIT,in the interim the XCPD spec can be used) If there is any questions then we need to discuss internally and then follow-up with the spec factory and CCHIT that will be validating and certifying HIE network implementations.

Here are the scenarios for audit logging related to PD
1)	Synchronous PD request initiated by a gateway A to B.
2)	Synchronous PD request received by a gateway A from B
3)	Deferred PD req message initiated by a gateway A to B
4)	Deferred PD request received by a gateway A from B
5)	Deferred PD response initiated by a gateway A to B.
6)	Deferred PD response received by a gateway A from B

Another question is that CONNECT logs four audit events for each message(incoming or outgoing), which may not be needed. The event database logs the handshake between the various hops adapter/nhin/entity, inbound and outbound so having those hops recorded again in the audit database seems redundant. For the responding side we need one audit message for the PD message at the responding side. Seems like there is a lot of redundancy and do we need these extra events. Also need to consider what happens when the gateway crashes. Need to document if there are any limitations ie. any gateway situations when an audit entry may not be made, what are the implementation options at that point - would the events in the event database provide for some tracking to the adopter?
This is the first of similar tickets related to auditing. It seems that once the design or an understanding of how this will work is determined it should work similarly for all services.

Dev: Need high level design since this will impact auditing for all messages. Document constraints, and any implementation scenarios that adopters need to aware of say cases where audit is not possible and other workarounds. Document constraints 
QA: Identify test cases supporting the scenarios. Include fan-out testing as well. Also tests should include cases for both success and failure scenarios. We should be able to use the CCHIT/DIL tool for testing as well. 

REQUIREMENTS:
1) PD messages shall be audited at the gateway as referenced in the NwHIN specs and underlying IHE specs.
Spec references: NwHIN PD spec v2.0(7/27/2011), IHE XCPD Rev 2-3 (2011-08-19) Section 3.55.5.1 Security Audit Considerations. (using this reference and not the Rev 2-1 (2010-08-10) because it has been referenced in the CCHIT pilot test scripts)
Also see Audit checklist (CL PD Responder Audit.xls) provided by CCHIT for certification

2)PD messages shall be audited for all the possible scenarios as defined below
a) Synchronous messages
b) Deferred messages
c) Fan-out 

3)PD messages shall be audited at the gateway regardless of mode ie. standard vs passthrough mode.

4)Continue to support option to turn off audit logging.

5)Flexible design that allows for logging to database or log files or both

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
Design is documented along with constraints and any implementation notes.
Gateway audits the message for all PD messages(see checklist to validate)for all scenarios. 
Audit messages are spec compliant.
title: As a CONNECT adopter, I want to audit PD messages per ATNA specifications so that the PD audits are compliant.

description:
HISTORY: The CONNECT product will be participating in the Pilot for the HIE Certified Network program. The goal of this pilot study is "to 
assess the test procedures and tools that will be used in the final program and demonstrate and document the efficacy of its testing process." Before we start the pilot sturdy we are required to set up our environment and run a couple of Smoke test scenarios to validate that we are ready to test. This is a pre-requisite to start Pilot testing.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:

These are the tasks that need to be completed
 System under test has to be ready for testing - done
 Configure firewall to allow web services through from both ends - done
 Register an account in DIL - done 
 Download and install certificate from DIL - done
 Register Endpoints in DIL - done
 Load Test Data Load Set into Test Environment - process has been set up for loading data
 Enter in your Patient ID numbers for the patient correlation in the DIL - done
 Verify connection between test environment & DIL - done
 Complete and successfully pass the Smoketest Service Set

For detailed steps on how each of this should be achieved see the Pre-set up checklist- http://ensemble.cgifederal.com/sites/StanleyPSHCONNECT/EngagementDeliveryManagement/Release%20Specific/Release%204.0/Testing/CCHIT_HIE_Certified_Network_Pilot/HIE_Certified_Network_Pre-Setup_Checklist.doc.pdf

Environment for pilot testing
Version being tested - CONNECT 4.1
Determine what OS,App server will be used for pilot testing?- GF 3.1.2/Windows

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
Setup complete. 
Complete and successfully pass the smoke test service set.
Create new Jira tickets for issues found during test.
title: As a CONNECT product owner/adopter, I want to complete the pre-requisities for pilot testing i.e. pre-test setup and responding smoke tests so that we can proceed with pilot testing

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 supports multiple application servers. For details on the app servers and OS environments that the 4.0 release was tested on  refer to the release testing wiki link- https://developer.connectopensource.org/display/CONNECT40/Release+Testing. The WS environments supported by this release include WebSphere Enterprise 8.5 and WebSphere CE 3.0.0.2. CMS is using WAS 7 and SDK 1.6 for the OFM program. SSA plans to WAS 7 as well and will plan on taking 4.0 in the next 6-18 months. CMS is concerned about using CONNECT on a version that is not supported and requires that we test and support using their environment(WAS 7/IBM SDK 6). We received some input from CMS that JDK 1.7 may not work with WAS 7 or is not supported for WAS 7. THis was tested as part of CONN-279 and it was validated that it is indeed the case. On the other side JDK 1.6 is no longer supported and/or public updates may not be available after Feb 2013. However CMS does not see that them moving to WAS 8.5 for the next 5 years. While they would like to use 4.0 in the immediate future, they are concerned that they do not want to use it in an environment that is not supported or has not been tested. SSA has told us that WAS bundles 7.x with JDK 1.6 and hence they would need support in that environment as well.

The goal is to support our partners in their preferred environment, else they will not be able to use the features possible with 4.0.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
THIS IS A RESEARCH TICKET TO UNDERSTAND THE IMPACT OF MODIFYING 4.0 CODE TO SUPPORT JDK 1.6.
CONNECT 4.0 code base uses JDK 1.7. Test 4.0 on WAS 7 using JDK 1.6 and assess the LOE to make this change.
We need to also know if there any features that will not work if JDK 1.6 is used.

CONSTRAINTS: 
1)The development team would need to acquire licenses for appropriate versions of the WAS application server that the CMS OFM team uses. 
2)Work with the CMS dev team if there are any questions

BUSINESS VALUE:
Support partners as they move to CONNECT 4.0 in their preferred environment(WAS 7/JDK 1.6).
Help estimate level of effort to add changes  to support this environment.

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
Test WAS 7 running using IBM SDK 6. Document how this was done and issues faced.
Initial focus on Document Submission service. Address any issues found.
Note particularly if any features we think will not work as desired.
title: As a CONNECT adopter, I want CONNECT 4.0 to  be tested on WebSphere 7.x using  IBM SDK 6 to validate that CONNECT will work in my preferred enviornment

description:
HISTORY: The CONNECT product will be participating in the Pilot for the HIE Certified Network program. The goal of this pilot study is "to 
assess the test procedures and tools that will be used in the final program and demonstrate and document the efficacy of its testing process." For the pilot study we would be required to fill in a questionnaire.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
The HIE Certified Network Optionality Questionnaire lists about 62 questions that CCHIT requires all the pilot participants to answer. These questions discuss the options provided by the system in test. After doing a prelim read of the questionnaire it seems that it targets both the gateway and the adapters i.e.,the entire HIE system or implementation. 
Our goal is to provide answers to this questionnaire. However additionally, we want to use this spreadsheet to track where each of this functionality
resides in CONNECT or whether it is even available ie. is the functionality related to the question addressed in the gateway vs in our 'Reference Initiating/Entity adapter impl' or in our 'Reference Responding adapter impl' or 'Does not exist in gateway or reference adapter'. I have created new columns on the spreadsheet to support this

Update the spreadsheet with the answers(See attached spreadsheet). If there are any questions that need further discussion, make a note of it in the spreadsheet itself and coordinate with Deepthi and we can get clarification from CCHIT. 

Assumptions: Pilot testing uses 2011 specs. CONNECT version for the purpose of this ticket is 4.0.

BUSINESS VALUE:
Product team will be knowledgeable on the certification process and tools.
Product team will use the knowledge gained to help CONNECT adopters in the community that are seeking to certify their implementations with CCHIT.
Final Certification for CONNECT product and adopter implementations of CONNECT will be faster.

COMPLETION CRITERIA: 
Complete the spreadsheet answering all the questions.
Attach the completed version to the ticket.
title: As the CONNECT product owner, I need the CCHIT HIE_Certified_Network_Questionnaire to be completed to help determine the test cases that we will be required to test for.

description:
HISTORY: CONNECT 3.3 allows for an adopter to communicate with their partners using both 2010 and 2011 specifications.
Documentation related to the 3.3 design that talks about how CONNECT supports both versions of the specifications and the design from an initiating and responding side- https://developer.connectopensource.org/display/CONNECTWIKI/UDDI-Based+Backwards+Compatibility.

However there have been a few scenarios that the federal partners have identified when an implementation supports both versions of the specifications. The scenarios are related to the fact that the adapter does now know which spec version the inbound message is implementing to further process the message correctly per the rules and requirements defined for that implementation and create a version specific response.  

BUSINESS VALUE: 
-Support implementers that have strict validation procedures required at the adapter. 
-Adapters do not have to write logic to make the spec version determination in their adapters, so minimizes overhead for the adopters.
-Determining the message spec version and passing it off to the adapter provides a consistent approach for adopters, so that we do not have one-off rules or logic being implemented in the community(adapters)to determine what spec version is being implemented.

CONSIDERATIONS/DETAIL:
THIS TICKET IS A RESEARCH TICKET ONLY. THE DEVELOPMENT WORK WILL ONLY BE DONE AFTER THE DESIGN HAS BEEN APPROVED BY THE DE&I GROUP
Different versions of the eHealth Exchange specifications can have different requirements on the structure and content of given message. The requirement here is that the adopter needs to validate the structure and content of these messages differently depending on which version of the specification was used to construct the message. Therefore, when the adapter receives these incoming messages, it is required that the gateway tells the adapter which version of specification the message is supposed to implement.

Other notes:This is a new use case which was not reported during the 3.3 requirements process.
DoD is the reporting agency and SSA has inquired about this issue as well, although VA may also be interested in the solution. The "Dynamic Document" scenario is pervasive if not used exclusively from DoD's perspective.This change is being requested for PD, QD,and RD, however only QD, and RD have different validations for the different specification versions. 

Any design should not preclude adding this capability to all services.

Some examples:
Query for Documents(QD) - In Document Query 2010, dynamic documents are queried for by using requesting "DeferredCreation" in the status slot, while in 2011 dynamic documents are queried by providing the appropriate UUID in the XDSDocumentEntryType slot. In a positive case, these two elements could be used to route a message to a 2010 or 2011 validator. However, if a status slot is provided with a value of "Deferred Creation" and accidentally sent to a 2011 endpoint there would be two adverse affects:
1) The request would be unintentionally validated as a 2010 message.
2) The incorrect status per 2011 validation would not be reported.

Retrieve Documents(RD) - In document retrieve 2010 and 2011 the requests are the same, however validation could still be done on the responses from the adapter. The outlying scenario again is with the negative case. If a request comes in for an On Demand document on the 2010 interface, the repository or adapter would still respond with the additional new document elements (which would be dropped by the gateway), but this would be an invalid response because an on demand document was retrieved (sans additional metadata) from the 2010 endpoint. 

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
Research and determine what our design options could be to support the linked feature(CONN-46) with any pro/cons.
Add design approach page to wiki.
title: As a CONNECT developer, I want to research design options related to determining what version of the spec an incoming message is implementing to support partner usecase(CONN-46)

1)VA CR/CCR Number NHIN_CR453- Support policy check for Role=Medical Doctor
This is a policy check similar to Purpose of Use = TREATMENT, EMERGENCY, COVERAGE. 
Refer to attached document - process flow titled "VAP Policy Check - Inbound2" -future items in purple text. ----NEED THIS DOCUMENT FROM VA. 
This CR is dependent upon the Adapter being able to have access to the Role value thru the Gateway orchestrations and being able to provide to VAP.  GW versions 2.4.7 and earlier prevented access to Role. 

Potential Impacts: 
>changes to VAP policy check interface to accept Role as an input 
>changes to Adapter audit records to capture/store Role

2)VA CR/CCR Number- NVAP_CCR100 - Support Validation of  Authorization Assertion Role=Medical Doctor
This is a policy check similar to Purpose of Use = TREATMENT, EMERGENCY, COVERAGE. 
Refer to attached document - process flow titled "VAP Policy Check - Inbound2" -future items in purple text. 
This CR is dependent upon the Adapter being able to have access to the Role value thru the Gateway orchestrations and being able to provide to VAP.  GW versions 2.4.7 and earlier prevented access to Role.

Need further discussion with VA/product team to better understand this.
Need access to the documents that are mentioned in the email

HISTORY:
This ticket has been in the backlog for some time and CMS(2/28/2013) reiterated the need to support unsecured ports as needed for both their programs - CCSQ and OFM.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:

description:
HISTORY:
The NwHIN Exchange has transitioned from an ONC federal program initiative to a public-private initiative called eHealth Exchange. The Coordinating Committee designated Healtheway, a non-profit organization, to support the eHealth Exchange. HealtheWay assumed operation and support for the eHealth Exchange, starting 10/1/12 including Testing and onboarding. The new Testing team (CCHIT along with Aegis) has published test scripts that will be used for testing and onboarding participants into the Exchange.

Participant testing information can be found here-http://www.healthewayinc.org/index.php/exchange/participant-testing

Product testing information can be found here -  http://www.healthewayinc.org/index.php/exchange/product-testing
http://www.healthewayinc.org/index.php/resources/testing-program-resources/2-uncategorised/98-product-test-case-documentation

The Participant test cases have been validated successfully using 4.2.1 and other subsequent CONNECT releases
This ticket focuses on the product testing certification.

BUSINESS VALUE:
Adopters can participate in eHealth Exchange for PD, QD,RD services(since these are the only services that are currently being validated by Healtheway) using a product that is certified by eHealth Exchange.
Using an Exchange Ready System implies minimum or no risk to the adopters participating in Exchange.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
-Identify gaps in the CONNECT product (Release 4.X) for PD, QD, RD services and the functionality as defined in the  test scripts published by Healtheway
-Publish list of gaps
-Prioritize gaps and fix
-Test CONNECT and validate it is Exchange Ready for PD,QD,RD services (2011 version of messages will be tested)

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
CONNECT is a certified Exchange ready system certified for PD,QD,RD services
title: As a CONNECT adopter, I need CONNECT 4.6 to be Exchange ready and certified by the eHealth Exchange so that I can use a certified product for health data exchange

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 supports multiple application servers. For details on the app servers and OS environments that the 4.0 release was tested on  refer to the release testing wiki link- https://developer.connectopensource.org/display/CONNECT40/Release+Testing. The WS environments supported by this release include WebSphere Enterprise 8.5 and WebSphere CE 3.0.0.2. 

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
CMS is using WAS 7 and JDK 1.6 for the OFM program. CONNECT supports and has been tested on WAS 8 and JDK 1.7. CMS is concerned about using CONNECT on a version that is not supported and requires that we test and support using their environment(WAS 7/JDK 1.6). We have received some input from CMS that JDK 1.7 may not work with WAS 7 or is not supported for WAS 7. 
This ticket is to research and determine whether CONNECT will work on WAS 7 with JDK 1.7. 
CONNECT 4.0 was developed using JDK 1.7, both 3.3 and 4.0 were developed JDK 1.7. 
Also JDK 1.6 is no longer supported and/or public updates may not be available after Feb 2013. 


CONSTRAINTS: 
1)The development team would need to acquire licenses for appropriate versions of the WAS application
server that the OFM team uses. 
2)Ticket limited to testing with JDK 1.7 only (Validated w CMS)

BUSINESS VALUE:
Support partners as they move to CONNECT 4.0 in their preferred environment.
Clarify for other community users whether earlier versions of WAS will work with CONNECT 4.0.
Help estimate level of effort to add changes (if needed) to support this environment

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
Test WAS 7 running using JDK 1.7. Document how this was done.
Run the validation suite and document errors that were encountered.

Open questions - 
Get from OFM/CMS team - specific WAS 7 version to be tested on.
title: As a CONNECT adopter, I want CONNECT 4.0 to  be tested on WebSphere 7.x to validate whether CONNECT will work in my preferred enviornment

description:
The java adapter reference implementation of the policy engine (AdapterPDPProxyJavaImpl) is currently in the ConnectCoreLib project.  It should be pulled out into a separate project (plugin) and improved/maintained for any users wishing to use it.  The CoreLib component should be simplified to simple Permit/Deny classes.

CC: 
All policy engine reference adapter logic pulled into a plugin.  The plugin then would be reviewed and improved and the install process documented in a README.
ConnectCoreLib simplified including all Spring files updated.

Testing:
Plugin would be dropped into Connect according to the README directions and policy engine tested in adapter mode.
Test the basic CoreLib policy engine functionality for java permit/deny.
title: As a CONNECT Developer, I would like to pull out the Policy Engine adapter logic into a plugin, so that I can improve the policy engine functionality

HISTORY:
CONNECT 3.3 allows for an adopter to communicate with their partners using both 2010 and 2011 specifications.
Documentation related to the 3.3 design that talks about how CONNECT supports both versions of the specifications and the design from an initiating and responding side- https://developer.connectopensource.org/display/CONNECTWIKI/UDDI-Based+Backwards+Compatibility.

Fan-out includes the capability of initiating messages to multiple communities in parallel. It is a feature in CONNECT and was introduced in 3.3 for PD and QD services. It seems that while we discuss CONN-15 and CONN-46 which are enhancements related to the multi-specification support, we need to also make sure we understand the needs of the community with regards to fan-out.

QUESTION: 
Consider a fan-out scenario, where the entity adapter sends the gateway a QD 2010 message without <NHIN target communities> to the gateway
1)Is this a valid use case used by the federal partners and other community members? 
2)How should CONNECT broadcast? What spec version would CONNECT assume the message to be? Which HCIDs would it target - 2010 or 2011? This may be a limitation in the current 3.3 codebase.

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
Understand the use cases that are being used with fan-out in relation to the multi-spec discussion and create new user stories to support the scenarios.
title: As a CONNECT adopter, I need to understand how fanning out requests to multiple communities is handled with the multi-specification implementation in CONNECT

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. There is an implementation guide for Delivery notification that discusses scenarios related to notifying users or edge clients of a successful and failed delivery. This ticket is one among a series of tickets to support that capability. Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found at - https://developer.connectopensource.org/x/AgBVCQ

BUSINESS VALUE: 
Senders are kept informed of whether Direct messages initiated by them have been delivered or not to the final destination and may introduce workflow processes and steps to handle error cases.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
The issue is that a receiving STA's public facing SMTP server may reject acceptance of a message before ever performing security and trust operations. In these cases, the receiving STA returns an SMTP error code to the sending STA at the time of STA-to-STA transport. The message is never delivered to the final destination.
Possible Causes
 Sending STA has been blacklisted by the receiving STA's SMTP server
 Message exceeds size limit
 Invalid SMTP header format (invalid address format)
 Invalid message format

In some cases, the SMTP error from the receiving STA immediately indicates a failure status to the sending STA, and sending STA can deliver an appropriate failure notification to the edge client. In more complex deployment models, the sending STA may not aware of the SMTP error. In these cases, the sending STA will fall back to the mitigation steps as addressed in CONN-203.

OPen questions - Is this supported in the RI and can this be handled in CONNECT?

COMPLETION CRITERIA - For both SMTP and SOAP+XDR as edge protocol on the initiating side, Initiating gateway sends an error condition to the edge client when the message was rejected by the SMTP infrastructure at the responding gateway.
title: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive a failure notification when the Receiving STA's SMTP infrastructure rejects the message, so that I am informed of the failure and can take necessary next steps.

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. There is an implementation guide for Delivery notification that discusses scenarios related to notifying users or edge clients of a successful and failed delivery. This ticket is one among a series of tickets to support that capability. Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found at - https://developer.connectopensource.org/x/AgBVCQ

BUSINESS VALUE: 
Senders are kept informed of whether Direct messages initiated by them have been delivered or not to the final destination and may introduce workflow processes and steps to handle error cases.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
The issue here is when the edge client transports the message to its STA/Initiating gateway over the edge protocol(SMTP or SOAP), the gateway indicates with an appropriate error condition that it cannot accept the message.
Possible Causes
 Edge client is not authenticated or authorized
 Message is invalid

This is different from CONN-201 which is related to with processing of the message i.e. the security and trust validation fails.

Guidance from impl. guide -  This guide does not stipulate specific status codes or mechanisms indicating success or failure during the initial handoff of a message from the sender to the sender’s STA; these will depend on the edge protocols used between the sender and the sender’s STA.

Open question ' How is a successful handoff indicated with either edge client

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
 For both SMTP and SOAP+XDR as edge protocol on the initiating side, Initiating gateway sends a failure notification to the edge client when the message was not successfully handed off to the gateway.
title: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive an error notification when the Initiating gateway cannot accept my message due to some reason, so that I  can take necessary next steps.

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. There is an implementation guide for Delivery notification that discusses scenarios related to notifying users or edge clients of a successful and failed delivery. This ticket is one among a series of tickets to support that capability. Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found at - https://connectopensource.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=8585623

BUSINESS VALUE: 
Senders are kept informed of whether Direct messages initiated by them have been delivered or not to the final destination and may introduce workflow processes and steps to handle error cases.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
Initiating gateway/STA SHALL notify or indicate back to the sender failed delivery to a destination if no requested delivery notification messages are received from the Receiving STA after a given time threshold. Time threshold should be configurable at the gateway.These notifications will need to be supported for edge protocols SMTP (SOAP+XDR is out of scope).

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
THE CC BELOW APPLIES TO  SMTP  that are requesting tracking based on delivery notifications.Initiating gateway sends a failure notification or success notification to the Sender/edge when it has not received any negative or positive delivery notification from the responding gateway.

1)	Gateway sends a failure notification to the sender/edge when it when it has not received an MDN Dispatched or Failure notification from the Responding STA in a predefined time threshold. 
a.	This functionality needs to be supported for both edge scenarios on the responding side -SMTP and SOAP. 
2)	Timeframe is configurable at the gateway.
3)	Validate that if the gateway receives a MDN Dispatched or MDN Processed or MDN Failure after the failure notification has been sent to the edge no further notification is sent back to the SOAP or SMTP edge on the initiating side.
title: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive failure notifications when no requested delivery notifications are received from the receiving STA in a defined time, so that I can monitor messages that could have failed.

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. There is an implementation guide for Delivery notification that discusses scenarios related to notifying users or edge clients of a successful and failed delivery. This ticket is one among a series of tickets to support that capability. There is a also an implementation guide that talks about Direct edge protocols and discusses two methods of tracking - 1)Using Delivery notifications as defined in the Implementation guide for delivery notifications and 2)Using Processed notifications.(NOT IN SCOPE)

Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found at - https://connectopensource.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=8585623

BUSINESS VALUE: 
Senders are kept informed of whether Direct messages initiated by them have been delivered or not to the final destination as required by the use cases and may introduce workflow processes and steps to handle error cases.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
The message cannot be delivered to the final destination because the message does not pass security and trust validation in the receiving STA. Due to the failure, the sending STA is never notified of the failure. Also MDN processed notification was never received
Possible Causes 
• Trust relationship not established with sending STA 
• Sender’s certificate could not be resolved 
• Sender’s certificate is expired or revoked 
• Sender’s certificate does not meet receiving STAs certificate policies 
• Message is not encrypted or signed 

Initiating gateway/STA SHALL notify or indicate back to the sender failed delivery to a destination if no processed MDN message is received from the Receiving STA after a given time threshold. Time threshold should be configurable at the gateway.These notifications will need to be supported for both edge protocols SMTP and SOAP+XDR.(Only SMTP will be supported in Release 4.4 for delivery service notifications)

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
THE CC BELOW APPLIES TO  SMTP. (XDR edge is out of scope)
For SMTP  as edge protocol on the initiating side, if the HISP is tracking delivery notifications - 

1)	Gateway sends a failure notification to the sender/edge when it when it has not received an MDN Processed notification from the Responding STA in a predefined time threshold. 
a.	This functionality needs to be supported regardless of edge scenarios on the responding side
b.      This functionality needs to be supported regardless of how the edge is tracking notifications - via Processed(NOT IN SCOPE) or Delivery notifications.
2)	Time frame is configurable at the gateway.
3)	Validate that if the gateway receives a MDN Dispatched or MDN Processed or MDN Failure after the failure notification has been sent to the edge no further notification is sent back to the SMTP edge on the initiating side.
title: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive failure notification when a Processed MDN message is not received from the receiving STA in a configured timeframe, so that I can monitor messages that could have failed.

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. There is an implementation guide for Delivery notification that discusses scenarios related to notifying users or edge clients of a successful and failed delivery. here is a also an implementation guide that talks about Direct edge protocols and also introduces two methods of tracking - 1)Using Delivery notifications as defined in the Implementation guide for delivery notifications and 2)Using Processed notifications(NOT IN SCOPE FOR 4.4). 
This ticket is one among a series of tickets to support that capability. Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found at - https://connectopensource.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=8585623

BUSINESS VALUE: 
Senders are kept informed of whether Direct messages initiated by them have been delivered or not to the final destination based on their usecase and may introduce workflow processes and steps to handle error cases.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:

Implementation guide related requirements or considerations - 
•	Post-handoff, regardless of whether the sender and receiver share the same STA or are served by two separate STAs, the sender’s STA SHALL notify the sender of the successful or failed delivery of the original Direct message by delivering a positive or negative delivery notification message as defined in this guide; this delivery notification message MAY not be the actual positive or negative delivery notification that was originally issued by the receiving STA. 

•	Once the sender's STA has notified the sender of positive or negative delivery of a Direct message to a particular destination, the sender's STA SHALL provide no further notification to the sender of positive or negative delivery of that particular Direct message to that destination 

•	Whenever possible, the sender’s STA SHOULD notify the sending edge client utilizing the same edge protocol that initiated the message. If the original edge protocol cannot be used, the sender’s STA SHOULD attempt to notify the sending edge client using an alternative edge protocol, if available. If there is no suitable alternative edge protocol, the sender’s STA SHOULD implement a “dead letter” destination and offer a protocol enabling edge clients to retrieve delivery notifications from the dead letter destination 


COMPLETION CRITERIA - 
THE CC BELOW APPLIES TO SMTP EDGE ONLY(SOAP edge is out of scope for this ticket).

For SMTP  as edge protocol on the initiating side,Initiating gateway sends a failure notification or success notification to the Sender/edge when it receives a negative or positive delivery MDN notification or Processed notification from the Responding STA based on how the edge is tracking notifications.

1)	If the sender has requested for delivery notifications , gateway sends a failure notification to the sender/edge(SMTP or SOAP) when it receives a negative delivery notification from the Receiving STA
2)	If the sender has requested for delivery notifications, gateway sends a success notification to the sender/edge(SMTP or SOAP) when it receives a positive delivery notification from the Receiving STA.
3) If the sender has not requested for delivery notifications, gateway sends a success notification to the sender/edge(SMTP or SOAP) when it receives an MDN Processed notification from the Receiving STA.
4)Once the gateway has notified the sender/edge of positive or negative delivery of a Direct message to a particular destination, the gateway SHALL provide no further notification to the sender of positive or negative delivery of that particular Direct message to that destination
title: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive a notification  when positive or negative delivery notification message is received by the gateway from the Responding STA, so that I am informed of a successful or failed delivery

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. There is an implementation guide for Delivery notification that discusses scenarios related to notifying users or edge clients of a successful and failed delivery. This ticket is one among a series of tickets to support that capability. Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found at - https://connectopensource.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=8585623

BUSINESS VALUE: Senders are kept informed of whether Direct messages initiated by them have been delivered or not to the final destination and may introduce workflow processes and steps to handle error cases.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:

Due to an issue in the security and trust process in the sending STA, the message cannot be delivered to the Receiving STA, but the sending STA has already sent a successful handoff status to the edge client. 

Possible Causes 
•	Trust relationship not established with receiving STA 
•	Sender’s certificate and/or private key could not be resolved 
•	Sender’s certificate is expired or revoked 
•	Recipient’s certificate could not be resolved 
•	Recipient’s certificate is expired or revoked 
•	Recipient’s certificate does not meet receiving STAs certificate policies 


COMPLETION CRITERIA:
For SMTP as edge protocol on the initiating side,Initiating gateway sends a failure notification to the Sender if the message could not be sent to the Receiving STA after having successfully received it from the edge.
- This should be communicated via the edge protocol that initiated the message.
title: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive a failure notification when the message I initiated was not sent to the Receiving STA so that I am informed of a  failed delivery

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. There is an implementation guide for Delivery notification that discusses scenarios related to notifying users or edge clients of a successful and failed delivery. This ticket is one among a series of tickets to support that capability. Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found at - https://developer.connectopensource.org/x/AgBVCQ

BUSINESS VALUE: 
Senders are kept informed of whether Direct messages initiated by them have been delivered or not to the final destination and may introduce workflow processes and steps to handle error cases.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
As the Responding HISP, CONNECT will have the ability to respond to Direct messages with a successful or failed delivery notification based on delivery to the final destination, provided it was requested in the initiating Direct message.  CONNECT will leverage the RI components to provide this functionality
The final destination per the implementation guide is defined as either: 
o The message storage location (for use cases where the STA is responsible for providing message storage), or 
o The message being transported successfully over the receiving STA’s edge protocol to the recipient’s edge client (for use cases where the recipient’s systems are responsible for message storage). 
With CONNECT, this would mean a failed hand off to the SOAP or SMTP edge on the responding side.

Possible Causes 
• Delivery components are malfunctioning or unavailable 
• The final destination does not exist (invalid address). 
• The final destination is full (mail box over quota) 

Open questions–  
•	Need to understand what is a failed dispatch between the STA and the edge for both SOAP and SMTP, in other words the workflow at the responding edge client needs to be designed and discussed for a failed delivery i.e. what are the parameters and response for a failed delivery via SMTP and SOAP?
•	Does the RI use a negative DSN or an MDN with disposition-type=failed(both are valid per specs), but need this information esp. for documentation and implementation guidance.
•	Do we need to create an adapter for our implementation?


COMPLETION CRITERIA:
1)	CONNECT sends a delivery notification in response to a Direct message only if it was requested. 
2)	If delivery notification is not requested then a delivery notification (dispatched or failure) will not be sent.
3)	CONNECT acting as a Receiving STA will always issue a processed MDN once a message has been received and trust and security has been verified as required by the Applicability Statement(current functionality) 
4)	CONNECT shall send out a negative delivery notification upon delivery failure (see implementation guide Section 1.2 for details of the MDN message) 
a.	This functionality needs to be supported for both edge scenarios on the responding side - SMTP and SOAP.
title: As a CONNECT adopter receiving Direct messages, I need the ability to provide Negative delivery notification message to the Sending STA so that the sender may be informed of a failed delivery.

description:
HISTORY: CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. There is an implementation guide for Delivery notification that discusses scenarios related to notifying users or edge clients of a succesful and failed delivery. This ticket is one among a series of tickets to support that capability. Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found  at - https://developer.connectopensource.org/x/AgBVCQ

BUSINESS VALUE: 
Senders are kept informed of whether Direct messages initiated by them have been delivered or not to the final destination and may introduce workflow processes and steps to handle error cases.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
As the Responding HISP, CONNECT will have the ability to respond to Direct messages with a successful or failed delivery notification based on delivery to the final destination, provided it was requested in the initiating Direct message.  CONNECT will leverage the RI components to provide this functionality
The final destination per the implementation guide is defined as either: 
o The message storage location (for use cases where the STA is responsible for providing message storage), or 
o The message being transported successfully over the receiving STA’s edge protocol to the recipient’s edge client (for use cases where the recipient’s systems are responsible for message storage). 
With CONNECT, this would mean a successful hand off to the SOAP or SMTP edge on the responding side.

Open questions –  
•	Need to understand what is a successful dispatch between the STA and the edge for both SOAP and SMTP, in other words - the workflow at the responding edge client needs to be designed and discussed for a successful delivery i.e. what are the parameters and response for a successful delivery via SMTP and SOAP.
•	Do we need to create an adapter for our implementation - Not at this point.

1)This is only possible if the sender has requested for a delivery notification in the Direct message received by the Responding gateway. If notification request is not sent then the positive delivery notification(MDN) will not be sent.
2)Responding gateway acting as a Receiving STA SHALL issue:
 a)A processed MDN once a message has been received and trust and security has been verified as required by the Applicability Statement(current functionality) and
 b) a positive delivery notification upon delivery success (see implementation guide for details of the MDN) 
3)This functionality needs to be handled in both supported edge scenarios on the responding side -  SMTP and SOAP.The workflow at the responding edge client needs to be designed and discussed for a successful delivery i.e. what are the parameters and response for a successful delivery via SMTP and SOAP.


COMPLETION CRITERIA:

Analyze, Create a feature branch CONN-199(rebase it every sprint) and test.
1)	CONNECT sends a delivery notification in response to a Direct message only if it was requested. 
2)	If delivery notification is not requested then a delivery notification (dispatched or failure) will not be sent.
3)	CONNECT acting as a Receiving STA will always issue a processed MDN once a message has been received and trust and security has been verified as required by the Applicability Statement(current functionality) 
4)	CONNECT shall send out a positive delivery notification upon delivery success (see implementation guide Section 1.1 for details of the MDN message) 
a.	This functionality needs to be supported for both edge scenarios on the responding side - SMTP and SOAP.
title: As a CONNECT adopter receiving Direct messages, I need the ability to provide Positive delivery notification message(MDN) to the Sending STA so that the sender may be informed of a successful delivery.

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. There is an implementation guide for Delivery notification that discusses scenarios related to notifying users or edge clients of a succesful and failed delivery. This ticket is one among a series of tickets to support that capability. 
Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found  at - https://developer.connectopensource.org/x/AgBVCQ

BUSINESS VALUE: 
Senders are kept informed of whether Direct messages initiated by them have been delivered or not to the final destination and may introduce workflow processes and steps to handle error cases.

DETAIL: 
Direct messages initiated from CONNECT whether initiated via SOAP+XDR edge or via SMTP edge shall have the ability to include notification requests.  (Section 1.3 of Implementation guide for the message). CONNECT will leverage the RI components to provide this functionality

Open questions –  
•	Is there a use case to make it configurable? Not at this point
--------At the gateway level (i.e. all Direct messages intiated from the gateway will now have the request for delivery notification turned on or off?
--------By responding HISP or responding STA?
--------By recipient?
--------By edge making the request? - Current thinking
•	How are the adapter interfaces (SOAP and SMTP) impacted at the initiating edge? Will we need parameters passed in from the interfaces to indicate ‘Include Notification request’ yes or no? How is this set up in the RI.-- Edge client would need to ensure that the notification header is populated if delivery notifications are needed

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
1)	Specific Direct Messages initiated from CONNECT include the delivery notification request in the Direct messages sent out to the Receiving STAs.
     a.	The MDN request SHALL contain a Disposition-Notification-Options header (as specified by Section 2.2 of RFC3798) with a parameter named X-DIRECT-FINAL-DESTINATION-DELIVERY. This parameter SHALL have an importance of optional and a value of true.
     b.	Messages initiated via SMTP edge, include a delivery notification request in the Direct message
     c.	Direct messages will have a message Id in the message ID header that can help correlating the Message with the MDN and the delivery notifications. (current functionality)
title: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages  I want to have the ability to request  delivery notification messages from Receiving STAs, so that I am informed of a successful or failed delivery.

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. Since Direct was incorporated into the CONNECT codebase, the RI has enhanced its software and has released many versions of the Direct RI code. The most recent release of the Java RI is version 3.0. This version supports Trust Bundles in order to implement scalable trust in the Direct community. This ticket is one among a series of tickets to get CONNECT uptodate with the enhancements in the latest version of the RI. 
Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found at - https://developer.connectopensource.org/x/AgBVCQ

BUSINESS VALUE: 
1)Support trust communities implementing trust bundles. 
2)Reduce configuration overhead for the HISP implementers utilizing CONNECT with regards to setting up anchors and bundles at the HISP.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
Trust Bundle are a collection of trust anchors within a trust community that conform to a common set of policies and procedures. Packaged using cryptographic message syntax (CMS) and (S)MIME standards.Distributed over public URLs using HTTP(s) and are consumed by HISPs via the published URL.Trust Communities and Bundles are Scalable. Each HISP only required to sign federated trust agreement. All HISPs signing the same agreement "trust" each other. Trust bundle distribution is cumulative, secure, and systemic. Trust bundle URL is configured once, updates are automatic. Distribution uses a hub and spoke model allowing distribution to be centralized. Networks within a community are "complete"

Currently CONNECT 4.0 does not include a UI configuration tool that would help include trust anchors into the HISP configuration. With the inclusion of trust bundles concept, there is a also need to add tools to help HISP managers to manage these bundles. The Java RI implementation already includes this UI to add a bundle, refresh a bundle, view anchors in a bundle and also associate bundles with domains. It also provides a UI for DNS entries and certificates. 

This ticket is to leverage the GUI functionality from the Java RI in order to support HISP implementations using CONNECT.

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
Leverage the GUI tool that will help HISP implementers or administrators to configure trust bundles and domains with the trust bundles and manage the bundles including refresh capabilities.
1) Create a domain
2) Add a new trust bundle and assign to domain
3) View all trust bundles and trust anchors for a domain
4) View trust anchors in a bundle
5) Delete a trust bundle
6)Refresh a trust bundle
7)Add anchor certificates to the domain
title: As a Direct HISP implementer using CONNECT, I need a GUI for trust bundle configuration so that configuring anchors and trust bundles is made easy from an implementation perspective

description:
This appears only on *.36.3. The purpose of this ticket is to determine if this is an issue or not (we believe it may be a config problem).

The workaround was to update the event logging hibernate config file event.hibernate.cfg.xml (/export/home/gfish/IBM/WebSphere/AppServer/profiles/AppSrv01/servers/server1/connect_config/hibernate). We updated the file only to make it match the audit log hibernate config file, simply because that services was working. This issue only appears on WAS. The application server could test the datasource successfully.

Deployed 4.0 CONNECT+Direct Binaries to WAS and Event logging was not working for both Direct and Exchange services. A work-around was discovered in which the event hibernate file needs to be modified in WAS. This can be fixed in documentation for the 4.0 release. See CONN-187 for the permanent fix

* Confirm that this exists and is replicable.
* If this is a config problem that seems others may have, update relevant documentation.
* If yes, document the work-around in the 4.0 installation instructions.
* If yes, update CONN-187 with any relevant details.
* If no, close this and close-can't-replicate CONN-187.
title: Confirm that event logging hibernate file does not work with WAS in 4.0
Fix 41 medium priority bugs.

description:
HISTORY: 
CONNECT 4.0 includes Direct support as per the specifications for HISP to HISP cases. Since Direct was incorporated into the CONNECT codebase, the RI has enhanced its software and has released many versions of the Direct RI code. The most recent release of the Java RI is version 3.0. This version supports Trust Bundles in order to implement scalable trust in the Direct community. This ticket is one among a series of tickets to get CONNECT uptodate with the enhancements in the latest version of the RI. 

Requirements related to this feature and associated specification references and requirements can be found at - https://developer.connectopensource.org/x/AgBVCQ

BUSINESS VALUE: 
1)Support trust communities implementing trust bundles. 
2)Reduce configuration overhead for the HISP implementers utilizing CONNECT with regards to setting up anchors and bundles at the HISP.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
Trust Bundle are a collection of trust anchors within a trust community that conform to a common set of policies and procedures. Packaged using cryptographic message syntax (CMS) and (S)MIME standards.Distributed over public URLs using HTTP(s) and are consumed by HISPs via the published URL.Trust Communities and Bundles are Scalable. Each HISP only required to sign federated trust agreement. All HISPs signing the same agreement "trust" each other. Trust bundle distribution is cumulative, secure, and systemic. Trust bundle URL is configured once, updates are automatic. Distribution uses a hub and spoke model allowing distribution to be centralized. Networks within a community are "complete"

(NOTE - This ticket does not include the Admin GUI aspects of the Direct configuration, but is a validation of the Direct config web services in CONNECT)



COMPLETION CRITERIA:
-Consume trust bundles into the CONNECT/HISP configuration and validate that the trust anchors in the bundles are utilized during Direct processing of messages. 
-Validate that individual trust anchors(not configured in trust bundles) are still utilized for Direct processing of messages.
-Create test artifacts/scripts for validation
-Validate by also testing with partners at the Direct Virtual Connect-a-thon and document and issues found.
title: As a Direct HISP implementer using CONNECT, I want CONNECT to support trust  bundles to minimize configuration overhead for setting up multiple anchors and support the trust communities that use trust bundles

description:
When the purpose of use, and role information is not provided to the Entity Interface, Initiating Gateway should read the properties from the assertionifno.properties and populate the Saml Assertion Attribute Statments purposeofuse attribute value and role attribute value. Instead the Attribute Values are left blank.

As per the Authorization Framrwork Spec, these 4 Attributes are mandatory. There is no validation happening on the receiving gateway for these Attribute Values.

Please find the attached logs of the Initating Gateway, Responding Gateway server.log files, assertioninfo.properties in the intiating gateway, and the Original message from SoapUI to the Entity service on the intiating gateway.

Completion criteria:

* Make role and purposeOfUse mandatory
* If purposeOfUse or role is missing, throw an exception and do not send the message

QA:

* PR validator passes
* Run validation suite withouot purposeOfUse and/or role and there should be an exception
title: Purpose of Use, and Role Attribute values are not populated from assertioninfo.properties in CONNECT 3.3 Specification 1.1

description:
... so that changes to one or the other only require rebuilds of the affected code.

Discussion:
Right now we have a singly-rooted maven hierarchy, which allows a single command-line build (mvn clean deploy).  We need to break out from this model, and instead have multiple roots.  As a single example, CommonTypeLibs can be standalone.  What we can do is have CommonTypeLibs build & be versioned independently from the rest of the code.  We then use maven dependency management between the builds.

As a first step to support the concept of separated builds, this task is to extract ONLY CommonTypeLibs.

CC:
- CommonTypeLibs is a separate top-level mvn project.  We may be able to put common dependencies into a referenced pom file, but the strict parent/child hierarchy will disappear.
- CI for CommonTypeLibs is established
- CI for rest of project has correct build ordering established
- Release process for changes to CommonTypeLibs documented.
- POMs for dependent projects now reference the checked-in CommonTypeLibs jar.  Critically, we should *not* depend on a snapshot.
title: As a CONNECT developer, I can build core libraries and services independently from each other

description: As an adopter, I can configure CONNECT following a minimal number of steps using an intuitive GUI. I can see meaningful, pseudo real-time data on a Dashboard as part of this experience.

description:
There are generally three types of configuration files in CONNECT: properties files, Connection Manager files, and spring proxy files. CONNECT handles the caching of the .properties files, and the Connection Manager files with different code, while I believe Spring actually handles the caching of the proxy config files. Ideally, the same code should be able to handle caching, refreshing, and the various configurations along with those concepts (cacheRefreshDuration, etc) regardless of whether we are looking at an .xml or a .properties file.

CC: Investigate if/how Spring is caching the spring proxy config xmls.
Build a subsystem (could be just a couple classes) that handle reading a file, monitoring it's refresh time, cacheRefreshDuration, etc. Include all the features that current exist in either the current properties look or Connection Manager look up.
Create/Update Unit test per CONNECT development guidelines [QA/TESTING CONSIDERATION].

title: As a CONNECT developer, I want to consolidate caching of configuration files into one subsystem to simplify code and help code maintainenance

description: The eventdb, used by event logging has a timestamp column. In MySQL 5.1 timestamp doesn't support sub-second times. description:
Ticket needs updates to reflect the current plan.

1)Move the Interop servers to GFE
2)Update Interop scripts, identify what scripts and functionality needs testing
3)Automate the execution 
---------------------------------------------------------

HISTORY: The CONNECT interop lab is currently limited to 6 virtual machines which was adequate for CONNECT 3.3.1.3 testing. However, with CONNECT 4.0 and the addition of WebSphere and WebLogic testing, multiple application environments have been configured on one server which requires manual intervention to repurpose the "Universal gateway." This inhibits lights out interop testing.

BUSINESS VALUE: Adding three addition virtual machines (8GB RAM, OS TBD) will enable WebLogic, GlassFish 3.3.1.3 and WebSphere Enterprise to be available on their own dedicated servers will enable the reimplementation of the interoperability test harness because manual reconfiguration work will not be required. This, in turn will permit the interop lab to be included in the automated CI build process.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL: A quote for these additional computing requirements is required from Terremark and budget/funding must be obtained.

description:
... so that my local development process is as efficient as possible.

Approximate current time: 20 minutes.

To achieve a reduction of 75%, explore the following speedups:
- separate the build of core libraries such as CONNECTCoreLib from the services
- wsdl generation is performed multiple times per build, and takes 30s+ per generation.  Change this to a single invocation if possible.
- embedded glassfish startup takes a long time, again due to wsdl parsing.  See if GF can reuse the compiled classes.
title: As a CONNECT developer, the default build should take less than 5 minutes

description:
Right now we have 2 configurations when the handling of a message fails, which includes the direct processing followed by the edge client handling of the message: 

1. remove all messages from the server regardless of handling status
2. leave failed messages in the inbox so they will be re-processed. 

...in the case of configuration #2 the message can be successfully "processed" as an inbound direct msg, however if the edge client handling fails we leave it on the server and process it over and over due to configuration #2.  The requirement is to send the MDN back regardless of edge client handling - not at the end of the complete transaction.  A better solution for configuration #2 , leaving it on the server would be to move it to a separate folder. Then it can be manually examined and dropped back in the live folder to be re-processed after the condition has been resolved.

code should create the folder if it doesn't exist. 

CC:
Configure the app with a new option for moving failed msgs to separate folder. Misconfigure the soap edge client such that handling fails. Inbound Messages would be moved to the failed msgs folder. Test outbound.
title: As a CONNECT Direct Hisp Adopter, I want to manage failed msgs using a separate mail folder.

description:
Environment:
Initiating Gateway: CONNECT 4.0 Beta
Responding Gateway: CONNECT 4.0 Beta
Application Server: GlassFish 3.1.2.2
Java JDK: 1.7.0_09

Examination of the Audit Message content recorded for the Document Submission request and response messages were found to be not conformant to the underlying IHE specifications. Per the NHIN Document Submission Web Service Interface Specification V 2.0 published on 5/17/2011, the underlying IHE specfication to be used for defining the recording of the Document Submission request and response audit messages is found at http://www.ihe.net/Technical_Framework/upload/IHE_ITI_TF_6-0_Vol2b_FT_2009-08-10.pdf, section "3.41.7.1  Audit Record Considerations".

The CONNECT 4.0 Beta audit message recording of the Document Submission request was found to have the following non-conformant issues:
* EventIdentification - incorrect EventID (EV) values
* EventIdentification - missing EventTypeCode element
* ActiveParticipant - only one ActiveParticipant; should be at least two: Source, Human Requestor (if known), and Destination
* ActiveParticipant - the one ActiveParticipant appears to be a combination of Source and Human Requestor
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - only one ParticipantObjectIdentification; should be two: Patient and Submission Set
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - the one ParticipantObjectIdentification appears to be a combination of Patient and Submission Set
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Patient information, the ParticipantObjectIDTypeCode is incomplete

The CONNECT 4.0 Beta audit message recording of the Document Submission response was found to have the following non-conformant issues:
* EventIdentification - incorrect EventID (EV) values
* EventIdentification - missing EventTypeCode element
* ActiveParticipant - only one ActiveParticipant; should be two: Source and Destination
* ActiveParticipant - the one ActiveParticipant appears to be a combination of Source and Human Requestor (which should not be defined)
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - only one ParticipantObjectIdentification; should be two: Patient and Submission Set
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - the one ParticipantObjectIdentification appears to be a combination of Patient and Submission Set
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Patient information, the ParticipantObjectIDTypeCode is incomplete
title: CONNECT 4.0 - Document Submission request and response audit messages not conformant to the underlying IHE specifications

description:
Environment:
Initiating Gateway: CONNECT 4.0 Beta
Responding Gateway: CONNECT 4.0 Beta
Application Server: GlassFish 3.1.2.2
Java JDK: 1.7.0_09

Examination of the Audit Message content recorded for the Retrieve Documents request and response messages were found to be not conformant to the underlying IHE specifications. Per the NHIN Retrieve Documents Web Service Interface Specification V 3.0 published on 7/27/2011, the underlying IHE specfication to be used for defining the recording of the Retrieve Documents request and response audit messages is found at: http://www.ihe.net/Technical_Framework/upload/IHE_ITI_Suppl_XCA_Rev2-1_TI_2010-08-10.pdf, section "3.39.4.1.4 Security Considerations" which in turn reference the IHE ITI-TF Volume 2b specification: "See ITI TF-2b: 3.43.6".

The CONNECT 4.0 Beta audit message recording of the Retrieve Documents request was found to have the following non-conformant issues:
* EventIdentification - incorrect EventActionCode value
* EventIdentification - incorrect EventTypeCode element
* ActiveParticipant - only one ActiveParticipant; should be at least two: Source, Human Requestor (if known), and Destination
* ActiveParticipant - the one ActiveParticipant appears to be a combination of Source and Human Requestor
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - only one ParticipantObjectIdentification; should be two: Patient and Query Parameters
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - the one ParticipantObjectIdentification appears to be a combination of Patient and Query Parameters
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Patient information, the ParticipantObjectIDTypeCode is incomplete
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Document(s), there should be a ParticipantObjectIdentification definition for each requested Document
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Document(s), the ParticipantObjectDetail is not defined; it can be as the "Repository Unique Id" and home community id are known

The CONNECT 4.0 Beta audit message recording of the Retrieve Documents response was found to have the following non-conformant issues:
* EventIdentification - incorrect EventTypeCode element
* ActiveParticipant - only one ActiveParticipant; should be two: Source and Destination
* ActiveParticipant - the one ActiveParticipant appears to be a combination of Source and Human Requestor (which should not be defined)
* AuditSourceIdentification - should represent the Document Registry of the responding gateway
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - only one ParticipantObjectIdentification; should be two based on single found patient match: Patient and Query Parameters
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - the one ParticipantObjectIdentification appears to be a combination of Patient and Query Parameters
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Patient information, the ParticipantObjectIDTypeCode is incomplete
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Document URI(s), there should be a ParticipantObjectIdentification definition for each returned Document URI
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Document URI(s), the ParticipantObjectDetail is not defined; it can be as the "Repository Unique Id" and home community id are known
title: CONNECT 4.0 - Retrieve Documents request and response audit messages not conformant to the underlying IHE specifications

description:

Responding Gateway: CONNECT 4.0 Beta

Examination of the Audit Message content recorded for the Query For Documents request and response messages were found to be not conformant to the underlying IHE specifications. Per the NHIN Query For Documents Web Service Interface Specification V 3.0 published on 7/27/2011, the underlying IHE specfication to be used for defining the recording of the Query For Documents request and response audit messages is found at: http://www.ihe.net/Technical_Framework/upload/IHE_ITI_Suppl_XCA_Rev2-1_TI_2010-08-10.pdf, section "3.38.4.1.4 Security Considerations" which in turn reference the IHE ITI-TF Volume 2a specification: "See ITI TF-2a: 3.18.4.2.4".

The CONNECT 4.0 Beta audit message recording of the Query For Documents request was found to have the following non-conformant issues:
* EventIdentification - incorrect EventTypeCode element
* ActiveParticipant - only one ActiveParticipant; should be at least two: Source, Human Requestor (if known), and Destination
* ActiveParticipant - the one ActiveParticipant appears to be a combination of Source and Human Requestor
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - only one ParticipantObjectIdentification; should be two: Patient and Query Parameters
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - the one ParticipantObjectIdentification appears to be a combination of Patient and Query Parameters
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Patient information, the ParticipantObjectIDTypeCode is incomplete
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Query Parameters, the ParticipantObjectName is not defined; it can be as the home community id is known
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Query Parameters, the ParticipantObjectDetail is not defined; it can be as the QueryEncoding and home community id are known

h5. NOTE: The IHE specifications do not explicitly define the audit message requirements for the query response message. Requirements for this audit message should be confirmed with the Spec Factory.

The CONNECT 4.0 Beta audit message recording of the Query For Documents response was found to have the following non-conformant issues:
* EventIdentification - incorrect EventTypeCode element
* ActiveParticipant - only one ActiveParticipant; should be two: Source and Destination
* ActiveParticipant - the one ActiveParticipant appears to be a combination of Source and Human Requestor (which should not be defined)
* AuditSourceIdentification - should represent the Document Registry of the responding gateway
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - only one ParticipantObjectIdentification; should be two based on single found patient match: Patient and Query Parameters
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - the one ParticipantObjectIdentification appears to be a combination of Patient and Query Parameters
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Patient information, the ParticipantObjectIDTypeCode is incomplete
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Query Parameters, the ParticipantObjectQuery contains the AdhocQueryResponse message, only the AdhocQueryRequest message is referenced
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Query Parameters, the ParticipantObjectName is not defined; it can be as the home community id is known
* ParticipantObjectIdentification - for the Query Parameters, the ParticipantObjectDetail is not defined; it can be as the QueryEncoding and home community id are known
title: CONNECT 4.0 - Query For Documents request and response audit messages not conformant to the underlying IHE specifications

description:
HISTORY:

BUSINESS VALUE:


CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:It is still an open question within the eHealth Exchange specification factory as to what the auditing requirement is on the eHealth Exchange. It appears that auditing functionality will be tested as part of onboarding, however there are production scenarios where auditing is not required or explicitly left out. 

CONNECT currently allows this functionality, however when auditing is turned off, it is turned off at the proxy (by configuring the Noop implementation) level, which means that the audit message is still constructed. This is inefficient. If auditing is going to be turned off audit transformation should not occur. 

There is no requirement against adding a new configuration parameter. However there used to be an disable (or enable?) auditing properties, if this still exists it is a good candidate for this functionality.

This applies to all services, all versions, and both standard and passthru modes.

This requirement is not related to creating ATNA spec compliant audit messages.

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
title: As a CONNECT developer, I want to eliminate audit transforms when auditing is not enabled, to make the gateway run more efficiently.

description:
HISTORY: CONNECT 3.3 allows for an adopter to communicate with their partners using both 2010 and 2011 specifications.
Documentation related to the 3.3 design that talks about how CONNECT supports both versions of the specifications and the design from an initiating and responding side- https://developer.connectopensource.org/display/CONNECTWIKI/UDDI-Based+Backwards+Compatibility.

However there have been a few scenarios that the federal partners have identified when an implementation supports both versions of the specifications. The scenarios are related to the fact that the adapter does now know which spec version the inbound message is implementing to further process the message correctly per the rules and requirements defined for that implementation and create a version specific response.  

BUSINESS VALUE: 
-Support implementers that have strict validation procedures required at the adapter. 
-Adopters do not have to write logic to determine the message specification version in their adapters, minimizing overhead.
-Determining the message spec version and passing it off to the adapter provides a consistent approach for adopters, so that we do not have one-off rules or logic being implemented in the community(adapters)to determine what spec version is being implemented.

CONSIDERATIONS/DETAIL:
Different versions of the eHealth Exchange specifications can have different requirements on the structure and content of given message. The requirement here is that the adopter needs to validate the structure and content of these messages differently depending on which version of the specification was used to construct the message. Therefore, when the adapter receives these incoming messages, it is required that the gateway tells the adapter which version of specification the message is supposed to implement.

Other notes:This is a new use case which was not reported during the 3.3 requirements process.
DoD is the reporting agency and SSA has inquired about this issue as well, although VA may also be interested in the solution. The "Dynamic Document" scenario is pervasive if not used exclusively from DoD's perspective.This change is being requested for PD, QD,and RD, however only QD, and RD have different validations for the different specification versions. 

Any design should not preclude adding this capability to all services.

Some examples:
Query for Documents(QD) - In Document Query 2010, dynamic documents are queried for by using requesting "DeferredCreation" in the status slot, while in 2011 dynamic documents are queried by providing the appropriate UUID in the XDSDocumentEntryType slot. In a positive case, these two elements could be used to route a message to a 2010 or 2011 validator. However, if a status slot is provided with a value of "Deferred Creation" and accidentally sent to a 2011 endpoint there would be two adverse affects:
1) The request would be unintentionally validated as a 2010 message.
2) The incorrect status per 2011 validation would not be reported.

Retrieve Documents(RD) - In document retrieve 2010 and 2011 the requests are the same, however validation could still be done on the responses from the adapter. The outlying scenario again is with the negative case. If a request comes in for an On Demand document on the 2010 interface, the repository or adapter would still respond with the additional new document elements (which would be dropped by the gateway), but this would be an invalid response because an on demand document was retrieved (sans additional metadata) from the 2010 endpoint. 

COMPLETION CRITERIA:

Provide adapters for QD and RD services (responding side) the message spec version for the incoming message.
Tested and works successfully in Standard or Pass-through orchestration modes.
Design documented to detail how this was implemented, test results achieved and any known issues uncovered
Include in documentation adapter implementation guidance so adopters know how to pull and use the message specification version in their adapter logic
title: As a CONNECT implementer supporting both versions of the eHealth Exchange specifications, I need to know what version of the spec a message is implementing, so that I can validate the incoming message.

HISTORY: Known Issue from 4.0. In the changes to auditing for 4.0, the check for null in the message for HCID was changed from multiple (if != null) statements to a single try catch for NPE.  The change now outputs the stack trace for the null pointer.  This is unnecessary output and clutters the log and leads the user to believe there is an actual error where none are.

We are actually catching and handling this error. Therefore, we should not also throw it.

CONSIDERATIONS/DETAIL:

BUSINESS VALUE:Removes unecessary clutter from the log files. Users no longer see a false error in the logs.

COMPLETION CRITERIA: Stack outputs removed from PD transforms and any other related audit changes in all services.

Passes CI and spot check for no errors in log if no HCID is present for sender in PD request (along with any other found unneeded stack outputs).
title: Audit Log Transforms (PD) throws exception in server log
Deferred Queue Manager GUI: Document Submission deferred requests are not showing up in GUI

description:
HISTORY:
Post release (3.3) there have been issues discovered with the service that have been identified but to date have not been prioritized as high as other 4.0 release work in the backlog by the community. In addition, there have been changes made to the architecture to support features like lightweight gateway, support for multiple application servers and event logging in 4.0, these changes have not been completely propagated to the HIEM service yet. These are handled by other tickets/user stories that are linked in here. The goal of this ticket is to make sure that the bugs discovered in the past related to HIEM no longer exist and that the service successfully passes all validation testes.
Note - The HIEM service specification was also not updated as part of the 2011 specification updates like the other NwHIN services specifications. So the specification that CONNECT needs to support is HIEM v2.0(2010).

BUSINESS VALUE:
Support any adopter that wants to use HIEM service.

CONSIDERATIONS/DETAIL:

There have been many HIEM tickets that have been identified in the past. All existing bugs that have been opened related to HIEM Subscribe/Unsubscribe/Notify are linked to this user story. These tickets may or may not be applicable, but would need to be analyzed and fixed if still an issue. May need updating of validation tests.

COMPLETION CRITERIA : HIEM successfully tested and validated on WebSphere, WebLogic and GlassFish application servers. Validation suite passes.
title: As a CONNECT adopter, I need all bugs related to HIEM service for Notify, Subscribe and Unsubscribe to be fixed and HIEM service successfully validated so that I can use HIEM service
