description:
HISTORY:
Post release (3.3) there have been issues discovered with the service that have been identified but to date have not been prioritized as high as other 4.0 release work in the backlog by the community. In addition, there have been changes made to the architecture to support features like lightweight gateway, support for multiple application servers and event logging in 4.0, these changes have not been completely propagated to the HIEM service yet.The goal of this ticket is to bring HIEM uptodate with the architecture/design modifications done in 4.0 related to lightweight gateway and to make sure that it is specification compliant.
Note - The HIEM service specification was also not updated as part of the 2011 specification updates like the other NwHIN services specifications. So the specification that CONNECT needs to support is HIEM v2.0(2010).

BUSINESS VALUE:
Support any adopter that wants to use HIEM service.

CONSIDERATIONS/DETAIL:Implement lightweight gateway capability in HIEM
The following will need to be done to support lightweight gateway:

1. Remove msg proxy wsdls and endpoints
2. Modularize the orchestration (business logic) implementations for inbound and outbound.  One will have the entity implementation (audit+policy+send) and one passthrough (send only).  The idea here is that the orchImpl will be switchable in the spring config xml.
3. Use spring's PropertyPlaceholderConfigurer to configure which implementations to use.  This means a new properties file will be needed.

<bean class="org.springframework.beans.factory.config.PropertyPlaceholderConfigurer">
    <property name="locations">
        <value>classpath:com/foo/strategy.properties</value>
    </property>
    <property name="properties">
        <value>custom.strategy.class=com.foo.DefaultStrategy</value>
    </property>
</bean>

<bean id="serviceStrategy" class="${custom.strategy.class}"/>


Completion Criteria:
HIEM does not have msgproxy endpoints anymore.  Be able to switch the orch impl (entity or passthrough) for both outbound and inbound.
title: As a CONNECT user, I need the lightweight gateway capability to be applied for HIEM service so fewer endpoints need to be stood up for the service, memory footprint is reduced and HIEM is consistent with other services.

description:
HISTORY:
FIPS 140-2 is a government standard that provides a benchmark on how to implement cryptographic software. In CONNECT 4.0, CONNECT supported multiple application servers like WebSphere, WebLogic and GlassFish. We have assumed that WebSphere and WebLogic natively support FIPS, but we need to complete an analysis and testing effort to understand the configuration under which this can be achieved. There has been some work done on this during the 4.0 release, where the product team worked with the federal partners on (GATEWAY-3065). However, that work was not completed. This ticket is to address this issue and complete necessary work required to be FIPS compliant for WebSphere.

BUSINESS VALUE:
Federal partners can deploy CONNECT in their environments.

CONSIDERATIONS/DETAIL:
Do we need to work with the federal partners on this?  Which partners, resources and/or teams?  Other specifics of the task will need to be determined.

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
Installation instructions are uploaded to the wiki for WebSphere 7.0 and, if time permits, WebSphere 8.5.

PRE-REQUISITES:
1) Product Team needs to procure or needs access to a WebSphere 7.0 environment.

See CONN-387 for the corresponding WebLogic ticket.
title: As a CONNECT adopter I want installation instructions on how to configure and deploy CONNECT 4.x to be FIPS 140-2 compliant on a WebSphere 7.0 app server so that I can install CONNECT in my secure environment

description:
HISTORY: 
See GATEWAY-2936 for some background information related to this issue. The issue that was brought up during 4.0 was that CONNECT was not compliant with the WSA specs for MessageID which requires that the MessageID be unique. A write-up was created and brought up for discussion in the Spec factory call. See attached document(WSA Message ID Problem Statement). At the HealtheWay specification workgroup on 1/24/2013, it was determined that it doesn't seem to be an interoperability issue. For now, onboard testing will proceed with just a warning to participants if the <MessageID> is not unique. In the future they might fail participants. An official statement from the testing team is awaited.
During the course of 4.0 development there was another ticket related to multi-threading and CXF that partly addressed this issue.(See GW-3314 for details). CXF uses WS-Addressing Header <MessageID> to correlate request and response messages. Multi-threading the invocation with non-unique Message IDs during fan-out aggregation was causing CXF to not correlate the response with the request properly.  This was causing some threads to get multiple responses and others to not get a single response and consequently, timing out. In order to solve the issue for PD and QD fan-out, a new request with a new Message ID  is created for fan-out if there are more than one outbound targets. If there is only one, then the passed in Message ID from the assertion is used.This change was made to PD and QD fan-out for synchronous requests only. Deferred PD on the other hand uses a serial approach and is single threaded, so was not impacted and was not changed.
So currently the deferred PD fan-out does not use a unique MessageID which is a spec compliance issue. 

BUSINESS VALUE:
Compliance with the specifications and provide adapters  better tools for tracking responses.

CONSIDERATION/DETAIL: 
Note once the message IDs are made unique, there should be some way for the adapters to be able to track these back to the original message initiated. With the current approach the same messageID used in the entity interfaces are used in teh fanned out messages and so they can be traced back, but a new MessageID will break that pattern. So this needs to be re-designed. ALso in the case of Deferred PD Fan-out, the message responses are not aggregated but are sent to the adopter as the gateway receives each response. The adopter does not know of how many requests were sent out in the fan-out . This makes it difficult for the adopter to determine how long to wait and/or when all the responses have come in. Providing the ability for the adopter to track all request messages that were sent out in the case of fan-out will give them the necessary tools they need to determine how many requests are still awaiting responses. We may need to keep this in mind as well.

Also some guidance on how this impacts event logging or the Message IDs that are being logged needs to be provided.

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
Deferred Fan-out requests have a unique MessageID. Adopters have the ability to determine how many requests are still awaiting responses in the case of Deferred PD fan-out

PRE_REQUISITES:
Product team to populate product backlog and link to this feature - ready for prioritization.
title: As a CONNECT adopter supporting Deferred PD services, I need the MessageID for the fan-out requests to be unique so that the service is spec compliant

description:
HISTORY:
CONNECT has always supported audit logging since 3.x.. However, though the NwHIN specifications referenced the IHE ATNA specifications for audit logging, these were not enforced nor validated by the Exchange or the onboarding/testing team (pre-eHealth Exchange). There was not a decision made on whether audit logging was required or not for participating in the Exchange; it was assumed to be a best practice but not validated. Most partners used their own audit logging methods to manage audit logging. The CONNECT gateway also supports audit logging, but it does not completely support all the fields that are required and defined for the ATNA audit message for each service. In other words, there are still some bugs in the audit message content that need to be fixed in order to be specification compliant.

In 2012, NwHIN Exchange transitioned from an ONC federal program initiative to a public-private initiative called the eHealth Exchange. The Coordinating Committee designated HealtheWay, a non-profit organization, to support the eHealth Exchange. HealtheWay assumed operation and support for the eHealth Exchange, starting 10/1/2012, including testing and onboarding. The new testing body (CCHIT) has published test scripts for eHealth Exchange participant certification for onboarding/testing. These test scripts include audit checklists (for PD, QD and RD only) and provides instructions for a manual validation of ATNA message.

As of April 2013, the Spec Factory determined that the testing body should test the format of the ATNA message but that the transport (e.g., how the implementer sends out the audit message, such as syslog) of the message to some external repository is out of scope for testing purposes. Attached document (PRL Audit testing issue summary 20130117_jpm) indicates the approach proposed for testing audit logging by the testing team.  

Later in July 2013, CCHIT informed the CONNECT team that they will not be including ATNA audit testing in the eHealth Exchange participant certification program at this time. However the checklists are being maintained by the test team and it is our understanding that the test team reviews participant audit messages and provides warnings to participants if not compliant.

CONNECT will include enhancements to update the audit service so that the audit entries are specification compliant. Also while, it is understood that at this point eHealth Exchange does not enforce the audit message content to be specification compliant, this may change in the future and hence there is a need to be proactive and support CONNECT adopters that are participating in the eHealth Exchange

BUSINESS VALUE:
Compliance with the NwHIN and underlying IHE specifications for audit messages for eHealth Exchange participants and other CONNECT adopters.
Participants in the eHealth Exchange onboard successfully and produce ATNA compliant audit messages for gateway transactions.
Providing flexibility to adopters as multiple options for auditing are supported.

CONSIDERATIONS/DETAIL:

See wiki page for scope, requirements, scenarios and other detail related to this feature refer to wiki page - https://connectopensource.atlassian.net/wiki/x/lQGD

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
CONNECT audit log entries for PD,QD,RD,DS and AD services are specification compliant.
Requirements related to this feature as detailed in the wiki https://connectopensource.atlassian.net/wiki/x/lQGD are met.
Design is documented and available to the community.
title: As a CONNECT adopter, I want to improve CONNECT's audit logging across all SOAP based services so that gateway is ATNA compliant, auditing framework is consistent across all services and audit information is available for reporting purposes

description:

Details of the app server versions that have been tested can be found at https://developer.connectopensource.org/display/CONNECT40/Release+Testing. JBoss is another open source application server that is used by the community. Some adopters like  IHS (Indian Health Services) use JBoss in their environments and want CONNECT to be supported and tested on JBoss.

Greater adoption of CONNECT, Greater participation in the Exchange

CONSIDERATIONS/DETAIL:
Need further discussion and requirements on the following -  
1)Support latest version of JBoss 7.1 
2)Support on all 3 app servers (Windows/Linux,Solaris) 
3)FIPS compliance needs?
4)Any documentation needs?
5)Other requirements?

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
CONNECT is successfully deployed on JBoss. 
Validation suite for all services pass (PD,QD,RD,AD,DS,Direct). 
Installation and other supported documentation has been included on the wiki.

1)Need requirements related to the items included in consideration/detail.
2)Product team to populate product backlog and link to this feature - ready for prioritization.

description:
HISTORY:
CONNECT 4.0 supports the Direct project specifications and transport and allows for a CONNECT user to send and receive Direct messages via CONNECT gateway.


CONSIDERATION/DETAIL:
The Direct community will hold another virtual connect-a-thon on February 20th.  The event has three specific goals:
 
1.	Education on scalable trust, trust bundles, and how the Direct RIs are providing technical solutions (there will be a presentation and demo in the first hour of the event).
2.	Staging/testing for HIMSS.  This event will provide a playground for those attending HIMSS to kick the tires before March 3rd.
3.	Trust bundle field test.  Both the Java and .Net RIs will have trust bundle support ready to go in time for the event, and the ABBI trust community has offered to host provider and patient trust bundles containing your anchors.  This should simplify the process of publishing your anchors and establishing trust between other event participants.  See the event web page (under the red "NEW" section) for information on submitting your anchors to the trust bundles.
 
 
Event web page - http://wiki.directproject.org/Feb+2013+Connect-A-Thon

Email contact - Meyer,Greg [GMEYER@CERNER.COM]

COMPLETION CRITERIA:
1)Provide CONNECT test/instance information on the event web page
2)Attend education session on scalable trust, trust bundles. 
3)Understand what it would take for CONNECT to support the trust bundles
title: As a CONNECT developer, I want to participate in the Direct Virtual Connect-A-Thon so that I can test the Direct feature with other Direct instances and understand scalable trust, trust bundles

description:
HISTORY:
CONNECT 3.3 allows for an adopter to communicate with their partners using both 2010 and 2011 specifications.
Documentation related to the 3.3 design that talks about how CONNECT supports both versions of the specifications and the design from an initiating and responding side- https://developer.connectopensource.org/display/CONNECTWIKI/UDDI-Based+Backwards+Compatibility.

CONNECT 3.3 always "upgrades" to the responding gateway's supported specification. In other words, on the Initiating side if an adopter uses CONNECT 3.3 (Gateway A) and has selected to deploy only the 2010 implementations of the NwHIN specifications, when a request is initiated (through 2010 entity or passthrough endpoint) CONNECT 3.3 gateway communicates to the target CONNECT 3.3 (Gateway B which is provisioning both the 2010 and Summer 2011 specification implementations), using the Summer 2011 implementation version. 
CONNECT uses information from the Connection Manager (internalConnectionInfo.xml + the UDDI) to determine the target endpoint. CONNECT will always opt for the highest available target specification version. To "override" this functionality; if Gateway A and Gateway B decide that for whatever reason, they want their exchanges to support only the 2010 specifications, then Gateway A would need to indicate in its internalConnectionInfo.xml file that Gateway B supports only the 2010 endpoint. This will override the information in the UDDI, and limit the A-B exchange to the version indicated in the internalConnectionInfo file.

SSA has identified a scenario where they want to specifically target a particular version of the endpoint without having to reconfigure CONNECT.
The scenario identified is where a NwHIN participant deploys separate gateway applications to support January 2010 and Summer 2011 specifications. If the partner has problems with their Summer 2011 services, it would be useful to be able to force CONNECT to trigger the legacy endpoint (without having to reconfigure CONNECT). This API feature would place the effort on the adapter side developer to manage when triggering a legacy endpoint would be appropriate.

BUSINESS VALUE:
1)Give adopters greater flexibility by providing them the tools to trigger endpoints based on their use cases, deployment models, and trading partners capabilities.


COMPLETION CRITERIA:
1)Modify entity adapters in standard and passthrough modes to support targeting a specific spec version for a service.
title: As a CONNECT implementer, I want to instruct the gateway which spec version/endpoint  to target for a service so that I have greater flexibility when exchanging with my trading partners.
